The whole name of
the game of functions of several real variables-- in

in terms of the

That's what this whole

point is, notice this--

I keep saying the major point. I guess there's a lot of
major points about this. Remember that we did not
call arrows "vectors".

We did not call arrows "vectors"

Remember what we did? We told what it meant for

two arrows, and we

not call n-tuples a structure

until we tell how to
equate a pair of n-tuples, how to add a pair,

an n-tuple by a number. By the way, the structure

n-dimensional vector space,

or more concisely, n-space. And the idea works
like this-- let's

pick a particular value of n. Lets just call it n. And let S sub n be the
set of all n-tuples x_1

up to x_n, in other
words, the set of what? All n-tuples of
numbers x_1 up to x_n.

Let's pick two
particular members of S sub n, which we'll
call a-bar and b-bar. Where a-bar is simply
an abbreviation

for the n-tuple a_1 up to a_n,
where the a_1, a_2 up to a_n,

for the n-tuple b_1,

et cetera, b_n, where
b_1 up through b_n are also real numbers.

Now again, here's where
structure comes into play. We have already defined
an n-tuple arithmetic

in terms of arrows

Based on what happens when

following definitions.

First of all, we
invent the definition that a-bar equals b-bar means

by component. In other words, a_1

All the way up to what? a_n is equal to b_n. Now, in other words
again, what we're saying

is that for two
n-tuples to be equal, by definition, they should be
equal component by component,

and this is
motivated by the fact that we already know
that we've accepted this structural definition
for the case of arrows.

Similarly, given two n-tuples
a-bar and b-bar, to add them,

let me define that to be the
n-tuple that I get by adding component by component.

In other words, to find the
first component of a-bar plus b-bar, I add the first
component of a-bar

to the first component of b-bar. Noticing of course,

Be careful here. This is one number. a_1 plus b_1 is one number. a_2 plus b_2 is a number.

a_n plus b_n is a number. In other words, notice
that by this definition, the sum of two n-tuples
is again an n-tuple.

And finally, to multiply
a scalar by an n-tuple, I will agree to
define that definition

to mean that you multiply the
n-tuple component by component

by that particular
scalar, or number. Notice again that
all I have done here
